meanings.def: used to say that one thing can, will or might happen or be true, depending on another thing happening or being true
examples: If you see him, give him this note.
I'll only stay if you offer me more money.
If necessary I can come at once.
You can stay for the weekend if you like.
If anyone calls, tell them I'm not at home.
If he improved his IT skills, he'd (= he would) easily get a job.
You would know what was going on if you'd (= you had) listened.
They would have been here by now if they'd caught the early train.
If I was in charge, I'd do things differently.
(rather formal) If I were in charge…

meanings.def: when; whenever; every time
examples: If metal gets hot it expands.
She glares at me if I go near her desk.

meanings.def: used after ask, know, find out, wonder, etc. to introduce one of two or more possibilities
examples: Do you know if he's married?
I wonder if I should wear a coat or not.
He couldn't tell if she was laughing or crying.
Listen to the tune and see if you can remember the words.
She asked if/​whether I wanted a drink.,
We didn’t know if/​whether we should write or phone.

meanings.def: used after verbs or adjectives expressing feelings
examples: I am sorry if I disturbed you.
I'd be grateful if you would keep it a secret.
Do you mind if I turn the TV off?

meanings.def: used to admit that something is possible, but to say that it is not very important
examples: If she has any weakness, it is her Italian.
So what if he was late. Who cares?

meanings.def: used to ask somebody to listen to your opinion
examples: If you ask me, she's too scared to do it.
If you think about it, those children must be at school by now.
If you remember, Mary was always fond of animals.

meanings.def: used before an adjective to introduce a contrast
examples: He's a good driver, if a little over-confident.
We'll only do it once—if at all.

meanings.def: used with will or would to ask somebody politely to do something
examples: If you will sit down for a few moments, I'll tell the manager you're here.
If you would care to leave your name, we'll contact you as soon as possible.

meanings.def: used before could, may or might to suggest something or to interrupt somebody politely
examples: If I may make a suggestion, perhaps we could begin a little earlier next week.

meanings.def: despite the possibility that; no matter whether
examples: I'll get there, even if I have to walk.

meanings.def: despite the fact that; even though
examples: He is a great leader, even if he has many enemies.

meanings.def: used to say something about an event that may or may not happen
examples: If and when we ever meet again I hope he remembers what I did for him.

meanings.def: used to express an opinion about something, or after a negative statement to suggest that the opposite is true
examples: I'd say he was more like his father, if anything.
She's not thin—if anything she's on the plump side.

meanings.def: used to give somebody advice
examples: If I were you I'd start looking for another job.

meanings.def: used to introduce a different suggestion, after a sentence with if
examples: I'll go if you're going. If not (= if you are not), I'd rather stay at home.

meanings.def: used after a yes/no question to say what will or should happen if the answer is ‘no’
examples: Are you ready? If not, I'm going without you.
Do you want that cake? If not, I'll have it.

meanings.def: used to suggest that something may be even larger, more important, etc. than was first stated
examples: They cost thousands if not millions of pounds to build.

meanings.def: used to say that you wish something was true or that something had happened
examples: If only I were rich.
If only I knew her name.
If only he'd remembered to send that letter.
If only I had gone by taxi.

meanings.def: if that is the case
examples: Do you do research in your studies? If so, what research methods do you use?

meanings.def: used to say that something that is happening is surprising
examples: I'm surprised they've invited me to their wedding—it's not as if I know them well.

meanings.def: used to state the only situation in which something can happen
examples: Only if a teacher has given permission is a student allowed to leave the room.
Only if the red light comes on is there any danger to employees.

meanings.def: a situation that is not certain
examples: If he wins—and it's a big if—he'll be the first Englishman to win for fifty years.
There are still a lot of ifs and buts before everything's settled.

meanings.def: a poem published in 1910 by Rudyard Kipling. It consists of a single long sentence beginning with the word ‘if’, giving advice to a boy on how to become a man. It is in the Victorian tradition and now seems rather old-fashioned, but the poem remains extremely popular and is often voted the favourite poem of British readers.
